definition: to whistle
to blow/to play a wind instrument/to blast/to puff/to boast/to brag/to end in failure/to fall through
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
a whistle/sentry

sentences.english: Breathe out through pursed lips as if you were whistling.
sentences.chinese: 从闭合嘴唇中呼气，就好像在吹口哨。

sentences.english: She walks across a levee, blowing a whistle and waving her arms.
sentences.chinese: 她在大堤上走来走去，吹口哨，挥舞着胳膊赶鸟。

sentences.english: When they needed a refill, they used the whistle to get some service.
sentences.chinese: 当他们要新来一杯时，就用吹吹口哨叫服务生。

sentences.english: The boy whistled happily when he walked along.
sentences.chinese: 男孩边走边高兴地吹口哨。

sentences.english: Moondog did monologues, played bamboo pipes and whistles.
sentences.chinese: “月亮狗”会演独角戏，还会吹竹笛，吹口哨。

sentences.english: Q. Why do Chelsea fans whistle whilst sitting on the toilet?
sentences.chinese: 为什么车子球迷喜欢边坐在马桶上边吹口哨？

sentences.english: He whistled, and the dog came obediently.
sentences.chinese: 他一吹口哨，那狗就乖乖地来了。

sentences.english: From the darting blurs I hear an ominous whistling that chills my soul.
sentences.chinese: 从投掷的迷离我听见一不祥吹口哨冷颤我的灵魂。

sentences.english: The whistled sounds are surprisingly complicated and even almost birdlike .
sentences.chinese: 吹口哨的声音是令人吃惊惊且错综复杂和平稳的。

sentences.english: Just whistle and I'll be there.
sentences.chinese: 只要一吹口哨我就会来。

sentences.english: Whistle and hum at the same time.
But when he started whistling off-key, I'd had enough.
sentences.chinese: 但是，当他开始吹口哨了钥匙，我受够了。

sentences.english: I heard some of the audience heckle me with loud whistles.
sentences.chinese: 那天，我听到观众中有人大声吹口哨向我起哄。

definition: whistle
(lit.) blowing the trumpet/(fig.) to praise sb/(slang) to give a blowjob
to throw amorous or flirtatious glances at sb (esp. of a woman)
to pull a face/to grimace/to scowl
to heckle/rowdy jeering/to create a disturbance
shouting and screaming (idiom); to scream loudly/to rant/to kick up a racket/to conduct vigorous propaganda
to boo or jeer (as a sign of displeasure at an actor)
to pee pee (kiddie or feminine slang)
to shout loudly
to pass water/to piss/to urinate/to wee wee
to beat time

to play the xiao 簫|箫[xiao1] (mouth organ)/to beg while playing pipes; cf politician Wu Zixu 伍子胥[Wu3 Zi3 xu1], c. 520 BC destitute refugee in Wu town, 吳市吹簫|吴市吹箫[Wu2 shi4 chui1 xiao1]/to busk/virtuoso piper wins a beauty, cf 玉人吹簫|玉人吹箫[yu4 ren2 chui1 xiao1]/(slang) fellatio/blowjob
to sing a song
to blow a whistle/to whistle
to make eyes/to wink
out of tune/off-key
